{"comments": {"id": 27722, "count": 13, "talk_id": 9403}, "threadId": 27722, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "9403", "description": "Su Kahumbu raises badass cows -- healthy, well-fed animals whose protein is key to solving a growing crisis in Africa: childhood nutritional stunting. With iCow, a simple SMS service she developed to support small-scale livestock farmers, the TED Fellow is helping farmers across the continent by texting them tips on caring for and raising animals. Learn more about how this cheap innovation is helping feed hungry kids, one text at a time.", "event": "TEDGlobal 2017", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Su Kahumbu: How we can help hungry kids, one text at a time", "slug": "su_kahumbu_how_we_can_help_hungry_kids_one_text_at_a_time", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "3593", "slug": "su_kahumbu", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Su", "lastname": "Kahumbu", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Agriculturalist, social entrepreneur", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/094ec080d306e6c5da587c1ae7234ef5b654cd55_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "TED Fellow Su Kahumbu is working to improve farmer livelihoods and contribute to nutritional security and environmental sustainability.", "whylisten": "

Su Kahumbu creates cool mobile phone agriculture solutions for small holder farmers in Africa. Her solutions target improved climate resilient production methods that deliver on sustainable human, animal, crop and ecosystem health. 

Kahumbu latest baby is her award winning app, iCow, which is a comprehensive mobile phone based agricultural platform that provides farmers easy access to cutting edge sustainable agricultural knowledge, markets and experts. iCow is designed for low-end feature phones, helping users that aren't connected to the internet access to a database of rich offline content which they receive in SMS, 24/7 in languages of their choice. It comprises comprehensive content  on livestock, crops, soils, pollinators, insects and more and is currently used by thousands of small holder farmers in Kenya, Tanzania and Ethiopia in five local languages.

Kahumbu is a passionate social entrepreneur with 21 years experience of working with small holder farmers and organic farming systems in Kenya. Her goal is to inspire, enable and support farming communities across Africa by making farming sexy.

Kahumbu is based in Nairobi, Kenya where she heads Green Dreams Tech Ltd as the CEO. She is a TED Global Fellow, an advisory board member for Changing Course in Global Agriculture and the agricultural governor of the Mpesa Foundation Academy.

", "note": "Bill Benenson, Gene Rosow, Eleonore Dailly 2009", "link_url": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uHhhHpohglg", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "EXPLORE", "headline": "Infonet", "blurb": "Infonet, a channel of the Biovision Farmer Communication Programme (FCP), provides scientific and practical validated information and knowledge related to plant (crop), animal, human and environmental health. The resource gives farmers, trainers, students and extension workers quick access to up-to-date and locally relevant agricultural information and related topics. Infonet-Biovision's aim is to increase human and animal welfare and health, improve regional and local food security and at the same time conserve the environment and biodiversity.", "note": "", "link_url": "http://www.infonet-biovision.org/", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}]}]}, "more_resources": [], "corrections": [], "has_citations": true, "take_action": [{"status": "approved", "blurb": "**Come co-farm** with farmers in Kenya by sponsoring farmer education.", "link_url": "http://global.icow.co.ke/", "visible_url": "icow.co.ke", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": null, "type": "take_action", "verb": "join"}], "curator_approved": true, "description": "Su Kahumbu raises badass cows -- healthy, well-fed animals whose protein is key to solving a growing crisis in Africa: childhood nutritional stunting. It comprises comprehensive content  on livestock, crops, soils, pollinators, insects and more and is currently used by thousands of small holder farmers in Kenya, Tanzania and Ethiopia in five local languages.

author: Su_Kahumbu;
title: How we can help hungry kids, one text at a time

aws-transcripts.transcript: I want to introduce you to my bad ass friends, Meet Thelma and Louise. I'm passionate about cows, and although they've been getting into a lot of crap lately due to meet an emissions and climate change, I hope that I can redeem their reputation in part by showing you how incredibly important they are in solving one of the world's biggest problems. Food security. But more importantly, if Africa, its result in childhood stunting, stunting nutritional stunting manifests itself in a reduction of growth rate in human development. And according to UNICEF, stunting doesn't come easy. It doesn't come quickly. It happens over a long period of time during which a child enjoys painful and debilitating cycles of illness, depressed appetite, insufficient nutrition on inadequate care on most kids simply can't endure such a this, but those that do survive they carry forward long term cognitive problems as well as losses of stature. The numbers of stunted children under the under the age of five in most regions of the world has been declining. I really hate to say this, but the only place where they haven't been declining is here in Africa. Here, 59,000,000 children, three and 10 in that age group struggled to meet their genetic potential level. Genetic potential protein is one of our most important dietary requirements. An evidence shows that lack of essential amino acids the building blocks of proteins in young children's diets can result in stunting. Essential amino acids are called essential because we can't synthesize them in our bodies. We have to get them from all foods. On the best sources are animal derived milk, meat and eggs. Most protein consumed on the African continent is cropped based on. Although we have millions of small, the farmers rearing animals on life stopped. Production is not as easy as we think. The bid life stop gaps between rich countries and poor countries due to poor animal health. Endemic life stop diseases, some of them transmissible to humans, threatened not only livestock producers in those poor countries, but all human health across all countries. This is a global pathogens network. It shows the pathogens found across the world according to the in house Infectious diseases database, and it shows those pathogens that share hosts in a nutshell. We share pathogens on, thus diseases with the species. We live closest to our life stock, and we call these idiotic diseases, recent reports show. But the deadly dozen zoonotic diseases kill two point 2,000,000 people a 2nd 2 point 4,000,000,000 people annually. And Jimmy says the greatest burden of cyanosis falls on 1,000,000,000 poor life. Stop keepers. We totally underestimate the importance of our small, the farmers. We're beginning to recognize how important they are and how they influence on medical health, our bio safety and, more recently, our cognitive and our physical health. They stand at the front line of zoonotic epidemics. They pretty much underpin our existence, and they need to know so much. Yet most lack knowledge on livestock disease prevention and treatment. So how do they learn? Apart from shared experiences, trial and error? Conventional farming extension service is a boots on the ground and radio, expensive and hard to scale in the face of population growth. Sounds pretty gloomy, doesn't it? But we're at an interesting point in Africa were changing that narrative, using innovative solutions, riding across scalable technologies. Knowledge doesn't have to be expensive. My company developed it agricultural platform called Aikau. We teach farmers best livestock practices using SMS over simple low end phones. Farmers received three SMS is weak on best life stopped practices, and those that execute the message is going to see increases in productivity with in a shorter time is three months on those. The first increases in productivity, of course, are improved. Animal health. We use SMS because is retentive. Farmers store their messages. They write them down in books and in effect, we're drip feeding agriculture manuals into the field. We recognize that we are all part of the global food network, producers and consumers, you and me and every farmer on off. We're focusing now on trying to bring together producers and consumers to take action and become take responsibility for not only food security but for food safety. This beautiful animal is an African Asians I will crossed with a Dutch flick. V She's Milky than has I Will Mom and she sturdier and more resistant to disease than Affleck, the father in Ethiopia and Tanzania, the African Dairy Genetic Gains Program is using SMS and cutting a genomics and pioneering Africa's first tropically adapted dairy breeding centers and dairy performance recording centers. Farmers contribute their data, their production data, milking records, breeding records, of feeling records to the a d DD platform. This data is synthesized through algorithms from some of the top livestock institutions in the world before it lands back in the farmer's hands. An actionable SMS is customized data, customized responses, all aimed at increasing productivity based on the potential on the ground. We're in a very interesting place in agriculture in Africa. By the end of this year, we'll have almost 1,000,000,000 mobile phone subscriptions. We have the power in our hands to ensure that livestock production systems are not only healthy, productive and profitable, but that farmers and knowledgeable but more importantly, that are farmers are safe. Working with smallholder farmers is one of the best ways to guarantee food security. Working with smallholder farmers is one of the best ways to guarantee each and every child their full opportunity and ability to reach their full genetic potential. On harnessing the power of millions of smallholder farmers on their badass cows like mine, we should be able to bring the whole two stunting in Africa. Thank you
